commitResults.messageTitle: Renamed Duke to Elsria and added custom introduction
Added TaskList data structure and implemented to-do list
Added boundary checks for marking and unmarking tasks
Reworked command handling with Enums and separated Chatbot UI
add ToDo, a type of Task
Add Deadline, a type of Task
Add Event, a type of Task
Add abstract class Command for better command handling
rename ChatbotUI to UIHandler and add ChatbotContext class
Restructure project to make use of packages
Rework command system to use enums custom factory methods to create commands
Add Echo command and tidy up Command system
add other alias for Greeting and Farewell commands
remove unnecessary functions from Chatbot class
Use global constants for path name
Add full support for time conversion
Add Storage class to handle save/load
Make final changes for first release
Add full documentation to all Commands
Task class: add assert statements in deserialize
commitResults.messageBody:
Deserialize method just assumes that the correct
number of arguments are provided to correctly
deserialize and create a new Task

This could result in Array Access issues if
the number of tokens is not equal to the
number of arguments needed to create the
new task.

Adding assert statements at least emphasizes
how many tokens should the deserialized String
should have in order to create the Task.

Let's add assert statements to the deserialization
function in the Task class before Task creation.
Task class: add assert statements in deserialize

commitResults.messageTitle: Move Command implementations to impl package

commitResults.messageBody:
The command processing system has been completely reworked in a few
ways.

The initial system had the following problems:
1. Chatbot responses were hard-coded into the Commands.
   - Completely eliminates any potential to have multiple chatbots
     with unique dialogue.
   - Violates Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) as it does not
     make sense for Commands to contain dialogue specific to the
     chatbot.
   - It made reusing certain pieces of dialogue impossible, violating
     Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY) as well.
2. Commands all had the same constructor of receiving an Application
   Context and a Command Request
   - Command constructors were messy and unclear as the commands
     themselves only made use of some of the items provided
     within these wrapper classes.
     (eg. Greet command does not need anything from Application
     Context, but we are forced to pass it in anyway despite not
     using it at all)
   - This pattern makes more sense for Factory classes, as these
     would generate different Commands based on the same types
     of parameters.
   - This also makes error handling problematic as we are forced
     to run complicated logic within constructors which is not
     ideal (especially for AddCommand)
3. Commands all followed a simple call and response execution pattern.
   - Commands were inflexible with error handling. It was impossible
     to pause at any stage of the command execution because everything
     from parsing, to initialization, to execution were all part of
     the same phase.
   - Logic became very complex and bloated to all stages of command
     execution being part of the same phase.

The solution that I have came up with to remedy the aforementioned
limitations are as follows:
1. Create a DialogueMap class that holds all Dialogue for the Chatbot
   - This makes it possible to create multiple DialogueMaps in the
     future, allowing us to easily swap out a Dialogue Map for
     another to test the overall feel of the responses.
   - This promotes better SRP as the Chatbot now holds a Dialogue Map
     rather than having the Commands themselves containing it
   - This allows for reuse of specific Dialogues, like response for
     invalid arguments, or when arguments are of the wrong type, etc.
   - Dialogue paths enum facillitate easier navigation for the desired
     response
2. Refactor the Commands to have their own Parser and Factory classes,
and use a CommandHandler to handle command parsing and execution
instead.
   - This allows the logic for parsing, initialization, execution to
     all be easily separated.
   - It also allows for more complex logic as each individual Parser
     and Factory class could hold extra data that can be used for
     parsing.
     (eg. we can keep a tally of the number of failed executions of
     a specific command and use that to detext if the User is
     struggling and respond appropriately.
   - Each Parser and Factory is associated to the appropriate
     CommandType enum for easy lookup.
   - A complete parser and factory is used for generalised parsing
3. Upgrade the Command interpretation into a multi-stage pipeline
   - Current stages include Idle, Preprocessing, Intialization,
     Execution, Completion/Clean-up
   - Each stage of the pipeline returns a custom Response, which
     contains information about their respective status, which
     then informs if the pipeline should continue or not.
   - Allows for more flexible logic, such as pausing execution
     at later stages like the Initialization stage to allow for
     Users to rectify mistakes within their Commands (not implemented
     as of now)

An additional change is also overhauling the UiHandler and having
a base abstract Ui class which could be extended from.

Initially, ui handling for both CLI and GUI had completely separate
logic.

This makes ui handling confusing and lead to redundant code

This commit unifies both forms of UI handling under a shared abstract
ui class, which has minimally "say" and "response" functionality

This way, ui can be swapped out at will without needing custom code
to cater for it.

Future plans:
1. Implement Dialogue handling logic to make the appropriate
   substitutions and specified locations.
2. Clean up DialogueMap system to use a Tree Structure instead
3. Implement pausing in the middle of Command processing and
   the user to supplement data.
4. Improve UI
5. Improve Time parsing and display format

Let's update to this newest version to improve the code quality of
this project

Improve the Code Quality of the IP

Notable changes include:
Move Responses to a separate DialogueMap class
Add Individual Parsers and Factories for each Command
Overhaul Command processing to follow a pipeline
